I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In June 2009, the Government of Mongolia requested technical assistance (TA) from the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to design a public–private partnership (PPP) model for the 
implementation of a new combined heat and power (CHP) plant. This plant will help address the 
growing  energy  demand  and  provide  sustainable  energy  supply  to  Mongolia’s  capital, 
Ulaanbaatar, where the government also plans to retire existing inefficient CHP plants to reduce 
air pollution. This TA is included in ADB's country operations business plan, 2009–2012,1 which 
was approved in October 2009. The TA concept paper was approved on 24 August 2009, and a 
fact-finding mission was fielded from 6 to 9 July 2009.2 The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Mongolia has an extremely harsh winter climate, with temperatures of about –10°to –30° 
Celsius (C) during the day, dropping to as low as –40° C at night. In fact, Ulaanbaatar, where 
almost half of the population lives, is the coldest capital in the world, and its heating season has 
an unusually long duration of 8 months. Every year, the electricity and heating demand have 
increased  by  5%  and  6%,  respectively,  due  to  the  influx  of  people  from  rural  areas  to 
Ulaanbaatar who look for income-generating opportunities.3 In 2008, the incidence of poverty in 
Ulaanbaatar was 21.9%, compared to national average of 35.2%. Most of its poor residents 
(204,000 people or 46,000 households) live in an area known as Ger District.  
 
3.  From 2004 to 2007, the number of business entities in Ulaanbaatar has nearly doubled. 
Seventy  percent  of  the  total  registered  businesses  in  Mongolia  are  in  Ulaanbaatar,  which 
accounts  for  50%  of  the  country’s  gross  domestic  product.4 Presently,  their  heating  and 
electricity needs are met by three existing coal-based CHP plants, which are old and inefficient. 
The equipment in CHP plant 2 has been operating for over 40 years, in CHP plant 3 for 30–41 
years, and in CHP plant 4 for 18–26 years. While assistance from various donors has allowed 
these  plants  to  operate  fairly  reliably,  it  is  generally  agreed  that  most  parts  of  the  heat 
production system are nearing the end of their life. Moreover, although retrofits carried out over 
the past 15 years included some pollution control equipment, the CHP plants still cause severe 
air pollution in Ulaanbaatar during the winter months when they are operating at their highest 
capacity. According to a recent study on emissions, CHP plants 2 and 3 are major contributors 
of particulate matter in Ulaanbaatar.5  
 
4.  Considering the growing electricity and heating demand as well as the aging CHP 
plants,6 the supply-side situation is alarming. The current peak demand of electricity in the 
central grid system is 675 megawatts-electric (MWe), and heating demand in Ulaanbaatar is 
1,425 megawatts-thermal (MWth). The available generation capacity is 615 MWe and 1,524

6  Available capacity is 17.6 MWe and 43 MWth for CHP plant 2, and 105 MWe and 562 MWth for CHP plant 3. The

2   
MWth, respectively. If the operations of CHP plants 2 and 3 are interrupted—likely scenario for 
30-year-old equipment—the available capacity will be reduced to 492 MWe and 919 MWth, 
which will result in serious shortages. Thus, there is an urgent need to implement a new CHP 
plant to address the vulnerability of power and heating supply in Ulaanbaatar. A reliable heating 
supply is critical both for the population, as well as to sustain economic activities and welfare. 
 
5.  The government included the new CHP plant 5 among its top priorities in its action plan 
for 2008–2012.7 Its proposed capacity is 300 MWe and 813 MWth (700 gigacalories) with 45% 
of targeted thermal efficiency,8  which will enable it to (i) meet growing energy demand resulting 
from rapid urbanization and economic development led by the mining and housing construction 
sectors, (ii) reduce urban air pollution by retiring CHP plants 2 and 3, and (iii) improve the 
security of energy supply to the capital city.  
 
6.  In  Ulaanbaatar,  the  use  of  CHP  technology  is  highly  advantageous,  because  the 
combined electricity and heating demand is for over 5 months per year. During this period, 
much of the heat that is vented into the atmosphere can be recovered to heat water to about 
160° C and circulate it to keep homes and other buildings warm.9 According to the International 
Energy Agency, CHP technology results in up to 27% lower coal consumption than conventional 
electricity generation power plant without cogeneration of heat; lower emission of particulate 
matter that causes air pollution; and lower carbon dioxide emissions, which are responsible for 
global climate change.10 
 
7.  In  Mongolia,  private  investment  in  infrastructure  and  municipal  service  delivery  is 
expected to play a catalytic role in improving efficiency and quality of public service as well as 
rationalize state expenditure. The government initially wanted the private sector to design, 
finance, construct, and operate CHP plant 5. It invited bids through international competition 
from potential project developers in early 2008; the bidders were also required to propose a 
financing package for the project. About 20 potential investors purchased the bid document, but 
only one bid was submitted, which was evaluated as incomplete.11 The bidder subsequently 
withdrew. Although the process indicated strong international interest in the project, its failure 
demonstrated a weak private sector investment environment in Mongolia. Another lesson is that 
the private sector seems unwilling to take on all risks like a merchant plant. Thus, a public–
private partnership (PPP) approach is preferable, as the government will also share part of the 
perceived risks, thereby improving the overall risk profile for private investment.  
 
8.  But the existing PPP environment is also challenging due to the absence of an effective 
policy, legal and regulatory framework, which is essential to attract private investment. An ADB–
financed  TA  study  is  currently  underway  to  assist  the  Government  formulate  an  enabling 
environment for PPP through setting up a legal and institutional framework.12 This TA has 
provided assistance in (i) drafting a Concession Law, which was passed by Parliament in 
January 2010 and will become effective on 1 March 2010; and (ii) designing an institutional

development framework for a PPP unit13 to support government efforts to engage in more PPP 
projects. The proposed CHP 5 is expected to be among the first opportunities under this 
improved PPP framework. But apart from the policy and legal barriers at national level, there are 
still many critical sector and project related issues which may impact on the CHP 5 attracting 
private investment. The sector issues mainly arise due to weak sector governance, inefficient 
operation, subsidy driven non-transparent tariff setting principles, chronically weak financial 
performance of sector entities and offtaker's credit worthiness. Due to the limited large-scale 
capital works being undertaken in the sector, the technical and management capacity of staff to 
conduct bidding for a major infrastructure project is generally weak. The bidding document 
prepared for seeking private investment (para. 7) had critical deficiencies that led to its failure.14  
 
9.  In parallel to improving the bidding documents, assessment of project specific risks for 
private investors is needed in close cooperation with the PPP unit. Appropriate risk allocation 
between  public  and  private  sectors  and  suitable  risk  mitigation  approaches  are  critical  to 
encourage  private  investors  to  participate  in  infrastructure  and  municipal  service  delivery 
concessions. The PPP approach for the proposed CHP plant 5 will provide valuable insights 
and lessons in terms of the need for further reform of the enabling environment for PPPs, with a 
view to attracting future PPP transactions. 
 
10.  The proposed CHP plant 5 is in line with (i) Mongolia’s energy sector master plan for 
2002;15 (ii) state policy on fuel and energy from 2008;16 and (iii) the government’s action plan, 
2008–2012 (footnote 7). It is also in line with ADB's sector priorities and Strategy 202017 to 
address environmental sustainability of a key infrastructure project. Furthermore, ADB's country 
strategy and program, 2006–200818 identifies inclusive social development and stable broad-
based economic growth as two strategic pillars, and the absence of reliable electricity and 
heating services in the capital city could be major constraints to achieving these pillars.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
11.  The TA aims to address growing energy demand, provide a sustainable energy supply in 
Ulaanbaatar through the use of CHP technology and PPP, and retire inefficient power plants to 
reduce air pollution in the city. The TA will assist the government in (i) preparing a technical 
study  on  the  proposed  CHP  plant  5  that  includes  technical  specifications,  plant  boundary 
conditions, financial and economic analyses, and social and environmental safeguard issues; 
                                                 
13 The PPP unit is to manage PPP transactions and be a resource for PPP related knowledge and procedures. 
Adopting  best  practices,  the  unit  will  provide  guidance  and  assistance  on:  (i)  organizing  tenders,  (ii) 
evaluating contracts, (iii) concession agreements, or contract clauses, and (iv) detailed procedures for identifying, 
evaluating, and procuring PPPs. The unit will interface with transaction advisers, line ministers and the private 
party. The unit will be part of the State Property Committee. The unit was assigned this role in the State Policy on 
PPP, adopted last year and their role is codified in the Concession Law.

that accounted for the retirement of existing CHP plants; (v) clarity regarding the structure of the investment; (vi) 
sources of water and start-up power supply; (vii) land availability; (viii) approval status of the environmental impact 
assessment; and (ix) tariffs for electricity, water, and coal.

(ii) assessing sector issues; (iii) identifying various options for project financing and operation as 
a PPP; and (iv) organizing workshops and preparing a policy note for knowledge dissemination. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The TA impact will be improved security of energy supply for Ulaanbaatar. CHP plant 5 
is expected to be constructed by 2014. The TA outcome will be a suitably designed PPP model 
for the implementation of CHP plant 5. The TA recommendations are expected to be accepted 
by the government by September 2010. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The key outputs of the TA will include the following.  
(i)  Technical  study.  For  CHP  plant  5,  the  TA  will  (a)  determine  the  plant 
specifications and performance parameters, (b) conduct financial and economic 
analyses, and (c) conduct social and environment impact assessments.   
(ii)  Sector assessment. The TA will evaluate (a) tariff-setting methodology, (b) coal 
supply arrangements, and (c) power off-taker arrangements to ascertain potential 
risks. 
(iii)  Comparative  evaluation  of  project  financing  options.  It  will  identify 
alternatives  for  project  financing  and  operation  in  PPP,  such  as  
build–own–operate, build–own–operate–transfer, or the government may finance 
construction of the power plant through borrowings and then seek long-term 
management  contracts  for  its  operation  and  maintenance.  The  TA  will  also 
ascertain the risks and recommend suitable risk allocation measures to attract 
private investment. 
(iv)  Knowledge dissemination. The TA will (a) organize workshops, and (b) prepare 
a policy note recommending future steps to improve the PPP environment, and 
prepare an investment manual for the power sector. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,700,000 equivalent, of which $1,500,000 will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. 
The  Government  of  Mongolia  will  contribute  $200,000  to  finance  the  cost  of  project 
implementing unit. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook.19 The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 9 months, from May 2010 to January 2011. 
 
16.  The executing agency will be the Ministry of Mineral Resources and Energy (MMRE) 
and the implementing agency will be the project implementing unit under the Energy Agency.20 
MMRE  and  the  implementing  agency  will  provide  support  to  the  consultants,  including 
(i) adequately heated office space (with basic furniture, an international telephone line, and

(iii) assistance with visas, accommodation, and other permits required by the consultants to 
enter and to work; and (iv) access to all data, including documents, reports, accounts, drawings

17.  The  TA  will  require  a  total  of  105  person-months  of  consulting  services  (38  
person-months of international and 67 person-months of national). The required consultants will 
consist of an (i) energy specialist; (ii) boiler and turbine specialist; (iii) power specialist; (iv) 
electric specialist; (v) combustion specialist; (vi) communication and information specialist; (vii) 
district heating specialist; (viii) financial specialist; (ix) economist; (x) environmental specialist 
(air  quality,  water,  noise);  (xi)  civil  engineering  specialist;  (xii)  chemical  specialist;  (xiii) 
geological  specialist;  (xiv)  geodesy  specialist;  (xv)  resettlement  specialist;  and  (xvi)  PPP 
specialist. ADB will engage an international consulting firm, using a full technical proposal and 
the quality- and cost-based selection method based on the standard cost ratio of 80:20, in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). The consultants will work in close collaboration with MMRE and the implementing agency 
to ensure effective knowledge transfer. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
Further, ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) will be followed, 
and the shopping method used to procure necessary equipment.   
 
18.  The consultants will submit the following reports both in English and Mongolian: (i) an 
inception report to be submitted within 1 week after mobilization, (ii) a midterm report to be 
submitted within 3 months after mobilization, (iii) a draft final report to be submitted within 5 
months  after  mobilization,  and  (iv)  a  final  report  to  be  submitted  within  7  months  after 
mobilization. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Mongolia  for Ulaanbaatar  Low  Carbon  Energy  Supply  Project  Using  a 
Public–Private Partnership Model, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  For this technical assistance (TA), a consulting firm will provide a team of international 
and  national  consultants,  with  indicative  inputs  by  specialist  as  shown  in  Table  A3.  The 
consultants will work closely with the recently established PPP unit, especially in the design of 
the  proposed  approach,  and  drawing  on  the  lessons  learned.  The  terms  of  reference  for 
consulting services will include, but not be limited to, the following. 
 
A.  Technical Study 
 
2.  Demands forecast. The consultants will collect available information on Ulaanbaatar’s 
power supply, including the capacity, availability, and lifespan of existing CHP plants, power grid 
conditions, and power consumption. The consultants will conduct a power demand forecast of 
Ulaanbaatar for the next 10 years, estimate the gap between the power demand and power 
output, identify the problems in existing CHP plants and power grid, and evaluate feasible ways 
of connecting the new CHP plant to the power grid.  
 
3.  The  consultants  will  also  collect  existing  information  on  the  city’s  heating  supply, 
including the total existing district heating area, additional heating areas due to closures of  
heat-only  boilers,  total  heat  output  of  existing  heat  sources  (including  CHP  plants  and  
coal-fired boiler houses), district heating loads, network conditions for heat distribution, and 
planned increase of apartment buildings. They will conduct a district heating demand forecast of 
Ulaanbaatar for the next 10 years, estimate the gap between the heat demand and heat output, 
evaluate the possibility of connecting the new heat source with the heating networks and 
heating area, and assess the operating conditions of the district heating system. They will also 
discuss, with the Ministry of Mineral Resources and Energy (MMRE), their plan for CHP plants 2 
and 3 once the proposed CHP plant 5 is operational (i.e., whether to shut down the plants or 
individual units). Finally, they will determine the amount of heat and power to be produced, and, 
based on the power and heat demand forecasts. 
 
4.  Power plant justification, size, and technology. Based on the forecasted power and 
heat demands, the consultants will determine the power and heat capacities of the proposed 
CHP plant, and provide options for reliable operation of the main power grid and district heating 
system. Appropriate, reliable technologies that are energy efficient, cost saving, environmentally 
friendly, and easily maintainable and repairable will be selected through technical comparisons 
of various coal-based generation technologies, such as CHP, heat-only boiler, and combined 
cycle.  Key  equipment  suitable  for  the  selected  generation  technologies  will  also  be 
recommended through comparisons of available equipment. 
 
5.  Heat supply system analysis. Based on the analysis of the existing heat distribution 
system in Ulaanbaatar, the consultants will provide recommendations on (i) an optimal scheme 
to improve heat supply in Ulaanbaatar in connection with the proposed CHP plant; (ii) improving 
existing heat distribution capacity and operation conditions and performance of district heating 
pipe system and substations; and (iii) combining existing heating sources that work well with the 
new CHP plant, such as coal-fired boilers and additional CHP plants. 
 
6.  Site  selection  and  surveys. Proper plant location will be selected through careful 
surveys and comparison of at least two locations. The consultants will conduct (i) a general 
survey  of  existing  conditions;  (ii)  transport  condition  survey  on  specified  railway  and  road 
availability, including distances to the sites and evaluation of transport for coal and ash; (iii) 
water source analysis on total water consumption, available water sources, and a suitable water 
source for the new CHP plant; (iv) ash yard survey to develop an ash utilization plan to minimize 
the ash yard area and environmental impact from ash and to select proper sites for depositing

10   Appendix 3 
ash based on ash characteristics and estimated ash quantity; (v) geological study to research 
the stratum lithology of the sites, evaluate their stability to provide the engineered geological 
conditions for the CHP plant construction, evaluate the risk of earthquakes, and organize the 
groundwork; (vi) topographical survey to study the sites’ landform and ambient conditions in 
terms of the transport of construction materials, coal, and transmission of heat and power; (vii) 
geodesy surveys of the selected construction site to prepare the plan for the new CHP plant; 
and (viii) hydrometeorological survey on weather conditions. The consultants will also indicate 
the selected location of the CHP plant on the city general map or plan drawing, which should be 
included in the final report.  
 
7.  Coal  analysis.  Potential  coal  and  coal  supply  schemes  for  the  CHP  plant  will  be 
surveyed, and the coal quality tested and evaluated. The quantity of the CHP plant’s coal 
consumption  will  be  estimated,  and  the  serving  period  of  the  available  coal  mine  will  be 
assessed. 
 
8.  Master planning of the site. According to the site condition and working flow of the 
CHP plant, the main equipment, auxiliaries, and related buildings, such as warehouses, offices, 
and dorms will be well arranged on site. Necessary roads, grassland, and plazas will also be 
planned. 
 
9.  Main  equipment  design.  In  accordance  with  the  heat  and  power  demand,  the 
consultants will determine the total capacity of the CHP plant, key technologies, and quantity of 
main equipment. They will (i) determine the number of boilers and boiler types through a 
comparison of various coal-combustion technologies and other related technologies; (ii) select 
operating  parameters  and  boiler  auxiliaries;  (iii)  select  turbines  with  consideration  of  CHP 
generation including parameters, existing systems, and turbine condenser cooling systems; and 
(iv) select generators in accordance with the working conditions of turbines. 
 
10.  Power supply system. The consultants will assess or design (i) power transmission 
capacity and grid reliability, (ii) switch yards, (iii) double-circuit 220-kilovolt overhead lines to 
existing substations in Ulaanbaatar, (iv) uninterruptible power supply systems to power the 
distributed control system and instrumentation system to provide monitoring and control of 
critical plant functions during power interruptions, and (v) temporary power supplies during 
construction of the CHP plant. 
 
11.  Thermodynamic system. The main steam system, reheat steam system, extraction 
steam for district heating, and extraction steam for regenerative heating system will be rated to 
ensure high efficiency of the CHP plant. The steam system and condensate water system will 
be  included,  and  all  necessary  auxiliary  equipment  in  the  thermodynamic  system  will  be 
selected,  including  water-feeding  pumps,  feed  water  heaters,  oxygen  removers,  steam 
condensers, and condensate water pumps. 
 
12.  Combustion system. The consultants will evaluate and select a (i) coal yard; (ii) coal 
supply system; (iii) coal mills, burners, blowers, and draft fans; and (iv) ash-handing system, 
including ash collection, disposal, and use. 
 
13.  Water supply system. The consultants will assess (i) circulating water and making-up 
water  systems;  (ii)  desalting  water  systems  for  boilers,  including  suitable  water  treatment 
devices,  chemicals,  and  processes;  (iii)  water  supply  systems  for  domestic  use  and  fire 
protection; (iv) wastewater treatment systems and reuse; and (v) sampling and testing systems 
for desalting water in boilers.

Appendix 3  11
14.  Control  system.  The  consultants  will  also  assess  (i)  supervisory  control  and  data 
acquisition systems for monitoring and controlling the system operation of the new CHP plant; (ii) 
relay protection and automatic generation control systems; (iii) distribution control systems for 
the boilers, turbines, generators, and auxiliary facilities with adequate redundancy, and a central 
location for overall system alarm management and data acquisition including all necessary 
protective  functions  such  as  the  safe,  orderly  shutdown  of  equipment  or  system  during 
emergencies; and (iv) fault-tolerant process controllers that will be able to modify the process 
controller function blocks online.  
 
15.  Civil works. According to the technical requirement and site condition, the consultants 
will assess the (i) main workshop, where the turbines, boilers, generators, coal bunkers, dust 
collectors, draft fans, and oxygen removers will be located; (ii) flue gas pipe and chimney; (iii) 
coal yard and coal-transferring building; (iv) ash yard; (v) water treatment building; and (vi) 
warehouse and mechanical repairs of factory, office, dorm, eatery, and bathroom. 
 
16.  Heating,  ventilating,  and  air  conditioning.  Suitable  heating,  ventilating,  and  air 
conditioning systems will be installed in main workshop, coal-transferring building, control room, 
office, dorm, eatery, and bathroom. 
 
17.  Pollution countermeasures. Appropriate technologies will be selected to mitigate (i) 
particulate matter in flue gas; (ii) sulfur dioxide in flue gas; (iii) nitrogen oxide from flue gas; (iv) 
ash and slag from the boilers; (v) fly dust from the coal yard and construction site during 
construction;  (vi)  noise  from  fans,  pumps,  mills,  turbines,  generators,  and  steam-release 
openings;  and  (vii)  pollutants  in  discharged  wastewater.  Active  measures  will  be  taken  to 
improve the environment at the CHP plant location, such as planting grass or trees.  
 
18.  Energy  efficiency,  water  conservation,  and  material  conservation  measures. 
These measures will include using (i) high-efficiency equipment, such as burners, fans, mills, 
oxygen removers, and pumps with frequency modulating; (ii) high-vacuum condensers; (iii) 
variable transformation loading; (iv) high temperatures and pressure steam to drive turbines; (v) 
modulated  district  heating  systems;  (vi)  insulation  of  networks  and  equipment;  (vii)  water 
conservation measures;1 and (viii) feasibility analysis of coal-water mixture technology. 
 
19.  Fire protection and safety. To ensure the safety, healthy, and normal operation of the 
proposed CHP plant, the consultants will evaluate (i) fire protection devices and measures; (ii) 
effective  safety  measures  to  avoid  harm  from  mechanical  faults,  creepage,  fire,  and  
high-temperature  steam;  (iii)  sanitary  measures  to  mitigate  potential  pollutants  harmful  to 
personnel; and (iv) necessary personnel to be employed. 
 
20.  Environmental impact assessment. The consultants will assess the environmental 
impacts of the proposed CHP plant and undertake an environmental impact assessment (EIA) 
in accordance with the Environment Policy (2002) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
environmental guidelines, and environmental assessment guidelines, as well as any applicable 
policies, procedures, or guidelines for environmental assessment required by the Government 
of Mongolia. An EIA report and resettlement plan, including an environmental management plan 
(EMP), 2 will be prepared to identify all environmentally and socially sensitive issues (e.g., air 
quality, water quality, solid waste, and noise), potential impacts that may be caused by the 
                                                 
1  These include (i) reusing treated wastewater in make-up water or for watering roads and grassland; (ii) using dry 
ash remover; and (iii) installing a water conservation management system, including water consumption monitoring 
and control.   
2  It will present estimated costs affiliated with the proposed mitigation and monitoring actions as well as the 
institutions responsible for EMP implementation. Also, it will include the proposed staffing and training requirements 
related to EMP implementation, institutional needs, and other necessary support for proper EMP implementation.

12   Appendix 3 
project  activities,  and  corresponding  mitigation  measures.  The  costs  for  implementing  the 
recommended  mitigation  measures,  environmental  and  social  management,  and  any  
capacity-strengthening measures will be included in the study. An EMP will be included in a 
mitigation plan and a monitoring plan according to ADB’s Environment Policy as well as any 
applicable policies, procedures, or guidelines for environmental assessment required by the 
government.3  
 
21.  Application  of  Clean  Development  Mechanism. To assess the application of the 
Clean Development Mechanism (CDM), the consultants will (i) study the proposed CHP plant 
and its applicability to the methodology, especially Approved Consolidated Methodology (ACM) 
0013/AM0076 and/or any other methodology; (ii) identify elements in the methodology that need 
to have deviations, and prepare a request for deviation in methodology to be submitted to 
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, (iii) indicate the likely emission 
baseline necessary for the methodology; (iv) help in documentation of prior consideration of 
CDM, (v) identify the additionality arguments and supporting documents for CDM; (vi) help in 
local stakeholder consultation preparation and documentation as per requirements of the United 
Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, and combine with ADB procedures; and 
(vii) identify the legal and regulatory requirements of the proposed CHP plant, e.g., minimum 
boiler efficiency. 
 
22.  Social  impact  assessment.  The  consultants  will  also  conduct  a  social  impact 
assessment,  which  will  include  (i)  conducting  preliminary  impact  assessments  on  land 
acquisition in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), and, if required, 
preparing a draft resettlement framework and/or plan in accordance with this statement; (ii) 
establishing the baseline social and poverty data related to the new CHP plant; and (iii) eliciting 
commitments from local governments to participate in the implementation of the CHP plant. 
 
23.  Public  consultation.  The  consultants  will  assist  MMRE  in  carrying  out  the  public 
consultation and disclosure process for the EIA report and resettlement plan to allow public 
awareness of the selected CHP plant investment and the envisaged related environmental and 
social impacts. The consultants will organize, in collaboration with MMRE, at least two public 
meetings to present the draft EIA report when available.4 The draft EIA report and resettlement 
plan will be made publicly accessible in accordance with local regulations. 
 
24.  Project implementation. The consultants will be responsible for (i) examining the site 
conditions, and defining preparatory  works necessary for CHP plant construction, such as 
clearing of the site; road access, water and electricity required during construction, logistics for 
transporting large equipment, and necessary supplies; (ii) formulating the project plan and 
implementation  schedule;  (iii)  outlining  contracts  and  agreements  (e.g.,  power  purchase 
agreement, heat purchase agreement, fuel supply agreement, and framework agreement) to be 
                                                 
3  The mitigation plan  will present the mitigation measures related to prevent or reduce the possible project 
environmental impacts as well as the approximate costs for these measures. A list of mitigation measures will be 
recommended  based  on  existing  and  new  regulations  and  enforcement  incentives,  installation  of  control 
equipment, and implementation of new procedures. Each measure will be described in detail, providing all 
technical  information  required  for  its  implementation  (e.g.,  design,  equipment  description,  and  operating 
procedures, as appropriate). The monitoring plan will include feasible actions to monitor the implementation of the 
mitigation measures proposed in the mitigation plan and the impacts of the construction and operation of the CHP 
plant. It will provide technical details on monitoring activities, such as methods to be used, sampling locations, 
frequency of measurements, detection limits, and definition of thresholds that will signal the need for corrective 
actions. Baseline conditions will be established and reported in the EMP for each of the indicators prior to 
construction, using information developed as part of the EMP. The monitoring plan will also include an estimate of 
costs required to implement such a program as well as the parties responsible to carry out this plan.  
4  Minutes, including questions and answers from the meeting, will be included in the final draft EIA report and 
resettlement plan. The public meeting will be announced in the mass media 1 week ahead of the meeting, and 
active nongovernment organizations as well as local authorities will be invited.

Appendix 3  13
negotiated by the successful bidder with the respective counterparts; and (iv) recommending the 
most appropriate bidding process5 in close consultation with the public-private partnership (PPP) 
unit created under the technical assistance to Support Public-Private Partnerships.6 
 
25.  Financial  analysis.  The  analysis  will  include  a  preliminary  cost  estimate,  financial 
analysis, and financing plan of the proposed CHP plant and also take into account (i) financial 
projections (e.g., balance sheets, income statements, and statements of cash flow) for 20 years, 
and key financial indicators and covenants; (ii) project cost estimates, taking into account all 
relevant financial costs; and (iii) preliminary financial analysis.7 It will also identify practical 
strategies and approaches to mitigate risks. 
 
26.  Economic analysis. The analysis will include (i) power and heat price structures, billing 
and revenue collection systems, and recommendations for necessary changes to ensure the 
future financial sustainability with an analysis of possible barriers to the changes; (ii) benefits 
from the new CHP plant to local governments and residents; and (iii) an economic evaluation of 
the environmental impacts based on the benefits transfer method. The evaluation will follow 
ADB’s economic evaluation of environment impacts. 
 
B.  Sector Assessment 
 
27.  The sector assessment will comprise  
(i)  District heating. The consultants will review and assess the status of district 
heating industry in Ulaanbaatar.  
(ii)  Power supply. The consultants will review and assess the status of the power 
supply industry in the central electricity system. 
(iii)  Tariff setting methodology. The consultants will closely work with the PPP unit 
created under the technical assistance to Support Public-Private Partnerships 
(footnote 6) and Energy Regulatory Authority. The consultants will analyze and 
evaluate the existing tariff structure of the district heating and power supply, and, 
according to local conditions, recommend appropriate and feasible tariff-setting 
methodology to maximize benefits for the poor and to minimize financial risks. 
(iv)  Coal resource and supply. The consultants will analyze coal resources that are 
available for CHP plants in Ulaanbaatar, forecast the market demand of coal, and 
assess the risks of coal price fluctuation and shortage.  
(v)  Water resource and supply. The consultants will analyze water resources that 
are available for CHP plants in Ulaanbaatar, forecast the future demand of water, 
and assess the risks of water resources depletion.  
(vi)  Off-taker arrangements. The consultants will closely work with the PPP unit 
created under the technical assistance to Support Public-Private Partnerships 
(footnote 6). The consultants will assess power and heat off-taker arrangements 
and the institutional capacity of the electricity and heating off-takers. They will 
also draw up recommendations to implement institutional changes or policy or 
legislative measures to mitigate certain risks.  
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
5  Single- or two-stage bidding, pre- or post-qualification, and with- or without-financing proposals. 
6 ADB 2009. Technical Assistance to Mongolia to Support Public-Private Partnerships. Manila (TA 7291-MON, 
$200,000, approved on 3 June). 
7  This includes calculation of the (i) financial internal rate of return, (ii) weighted average cost of capital, (iii) project 
revenue and cost risks, and (iv) relevant sensitivity analysis.

14   Appendix 3 
C.  Comparison of Project Financing Options 
 
28.  Based  on  the  findings  from  the  financial  analysis,  the  consultants  will  (i)  make 
comparative evaluations on financing options, and identify the most appropriate approach for 
the project financing;8 and (ii) provide justification and recommendations, such as extending 
certain fiscal and tax incentives to the successful bidder, to make it financially attractive. This 
exercise shall be closely coordinated with the PPP Unit recently established by the government. 
At the early stage of activities, the consultants will seek guidance from the PPP Unit on potential 
approaches that need to be evaluated.   
 
D.  Knowledge Dissemination 
 
29.  Based on the TA findings, the consultants will (i) organize workshops for stakeholders to 
communicate the features of the proposed CHP plant and how the Ulaanbaatar energy supply 
will be made sustainable, and (ii) prepare a policy note and investment manual in power sector. 
Preparation of a policy note will be led by the public–private partnership specialist (power).  
 
E.  Reporting 
 
30.  All required reports, including appendixes, will be submitted in English and Mongolian to 
ADB and MMRE for review and comments. The consultants are expected to deliver (i) an 
inception report (1 month after mobilization), (ii) midterm report (3 months after mobilization), (iii) 
draft final report (5 months after mobilization), (iv) draft environmental impact assessment report 
(4  months  after  mobilization),  (v)  social  report  (5  months  after  mobilization),  (vi)  final 
environmental impact assessment  report (2 months after submission of the draft), and (vii) final 
report (7 months after mobilization).
